On an after-inflation "real" basis, this is currently likely to be the worst year ever for a traditional 60/40 stocks and bonds portfolio:

1974: -25%
1937: -24%
1931: -24%
1946: -20%
2008: -18% https://t.co/9sSTDgSqvs

"60/40 has crushed just about everything, including a lot of the biggest, smartest institutions in the world the past decade. What sort of problems does that cause? And then let‚Äôs start to move toward what can we do about it?"
"And a lot of people just assume that U.S. stocks and bonds are always negatively correlated. And so in the bad times for stocks, bonds will do okay and vice versa. Is that a dangerous assumption?"

"It seems like the nightmare scenario that we talk a lot about as a potential that I think everyone assumes can‚Äôt happen...would really inflict the most pain is a scenario where both U.S. stocks and U.S. bonds do poorly."

@cullenroche @alphaarchitect @Rick_Ferri I don't know any direct/custom indexes that do short lending ...can be a material 10-50bps benefit for many ETF strategies.

As I've said for years, you can largely divide the investing & finance & fintech space into two firms/cultures:

1. How little can we charge and still run a good business that serves customers?

2. How much can we charge and get away with it?

When you're considering a tax inefficient investment at 4.22% in annual fees, recall the BASE CASE is a tax efficient global ETF portfolio that has a zero expense ratio. 

0.03% (and likely negative with short lending).

Despite this "go nowhere for over a decade and trading super cheap", China doesn't even rank in the top 15 cheapest countries according to our models...

lots of countries have been absolutely wrecked for a long long time.  most US investors spared this carnage recently https://t.co/wec2rpEgBA
strong Don Draper vibe here. need to find out where he got these sunglasses....

Chinese stocks have gone nowhere for 15+ years, and are likely to dip into single-digit CAPE Ratio valuations by month end. 

That's the lowest valuation perhaps ever. (hard to tell with 2004/2005 similar levels...)

For rest of this decade...will Chinese stocks crush it or lag?

Usually the body heals and symptoms go away after 3-9 months. Fingers crossed that's been my experience and I'm out the other side now, but man that was really dark period.

Finally got a Dr that had the same experience himself with vaccine, and had seen dozens of patients similar.

He said it was hard to diagnose and treat since the symptoms were so varied. Often the immune system would attack a previous weakness.

It got bad enough where I got all my affairs in order. 

The most honest response was "we've seen a lot of crazy shit the last two years...both COVID and vaccine related...and we just don't know".
I read all the academic papers...was it microclots? Did I actually have COVID back in 2020 and this was LongCovid?  Take aspirin, don't take aspirin...Maybe I'm losing my mind?

Altitude triggered it. Bio markers were jacked up all over the place, and visited cardiology, pulmonary, rheumatology, hematology,etc.

It was really hard to find info - some drs were curious, baffled, others "not my problem", and others were extremely dismissive / condescending.

I had two Moderna vaccines and was fine. Got the Pfizer booster and within 20 minutes had sharp chest pains. 

Three trips to the ER. First, thought I might be having heart attack. Second, BP was 190. Third my veins were sputtering. List of about 20 different crazy symptoms.

It's just important to be honest and transparent about the side effects. 

When you give 12 billions doses even a .1% or 1% reaction is still millions of people. 

Make sure you report to VAERS

https://t.co/A4VpKGkItl

I'll share my experience with the vaccineinjured as I would've loved someone to talk to when I was dealing with it.Feel free to DM me. 

I got absolutely wrecked for about 6 months.

I'm not anti vax - I also know healthy young people that died from COVID too. It's heartbreaking.

Stock markets historically hate inflation. In normal times (0-4% inflation) the average 10-year PE (CAPE) ratio is ~20.

> 4% inflation it's 13. 
> 7% inflation it's 10.

5. No exposure to value (all market cap etc).

I think value will add 1-2% over market cap over time. But more importantly, it helps to keep you out of total insanity situations which can cause total mental havok.

4. No exposure to trend strats.

More psychological and behavioral than anything. My main gripe with buy and hold is it craters when everything else is....which makes it hard to do the "hold" part. Trend often helps during crisis periods when you need money most.

3. No exposure to real assets.

8.5% inflation print this week. Do I need to say more?

2. Own way too much in local market. (ie US)

Been smashing everyone over the head above home country bias for years. Awful, terrible, no good idea that so many implement to their eventual regret.

1. Ignore fees and taxes.

Investors consistently pay too much. We all know that.

But investors also ignore impacts like tax structure (ETF vs. mutual fund arguably more important than expense ratio), short lending revenue, etc.

5 mistakes investors consistently make, retail and pro alike:

1. Ignore fees and taxes.
2. Own way too much in the local market. (ie U.S.)
3. No exposure to real assets.
4. No exposure to trend strats.
5. No exposure to value (all market cap weight)

So obviously the US is in Yellow Light mode (was darn close to Red Light recently and QQQs are there)....but there are some markets that are in Green Light mode, or as my friend Sjugg describes...

Cheap, hated, and in an uptrend!

This exercise really illustrates two insights...

1. The trend is your friend. 

2. Using only value is dangerous as you can still make money in expensive markets and bubbles. But you need to have a parachute exit for when the signal changes...

A simple way to think about stock markets...and returns in that mode back to 1920s in US.

Green Light: cheap, in an uptrend , 17%
Yellow Light: expensive, in an uptrend, 9% (now)
Red Light: expensive, in a down trend, 3%

trend 10-month SMA
valuation CAPE ratio at the time

As Eddie Vedder said recently, "learn to enjoy the struggle"....

It helps to have a plan. I happily share mine and have for years. But your plan is unique to you...

I'm updating my "How I Invest 2022" and should be out next week...stay tuned!

How will you respond? 

Will you blame the FED, or your neighbor, or your broker, or politicians?

Or will you take responsibility for your own investments & learn from the experience?

Many want to gamble and speculate and when they win, they take credit for it all. 

When they lose, they blame something or someone else. 

It's your money, your responsibility. 

Most old traders learn humility eventually and take pride in their losses and scars.

Asset classes like foreign stocks, tilts like value, well you know already about those....they can stink for a long time...on both a relative and an absolute level. 

The batting average for most of my trend following strategies is probably less than a coin flip.

Lots of losers.

I've made over 300 startup investments over the past 8 years, and I fully expect at least 100 to be total zeros. 

-100%. 

https://t.co/Q7hqih6FUa

Even broad asset classes spend about 80% of the time in a drawdown. 

Some can last for decades or more. 

To be a good investor you have to be a good loser...from 2014:

https://t.co/qQDtHQYGjZ

The S&P 500 is near all time highs, and yet there is a sea of red today and lot of carnage under the surface...

One day you'll have an investment, or all of your investments, that will go down a lot. 

Like 50-100% a lot.

We all have, and if not yet, you will.

I have no idea if inflation is here to stay. 

Historically speaking, if it stays at these levels, investors have assigned stocks a much lower multiple. 

Like 40-70% lower.

These are not my predictions, just the data.

Historically speaking.

Stock markets historically hate inflation. In normal times (0-4% inflation) the average 10-year PE ratio is ~20.

> 4% inflation it's 13. 
> 7% inflation it's 10.

We're at 40.

Outside of 2021/2022, the HIGHEST valuation EVER awarded US market above 5% inflation? 

23

So, as you review your marketing emails with everyone bragging about crushing it, maybe it would be wise to reflect and think...

What's NOT crushing it? And might we be closer to the day in which that strategy BEGINS crushing it?
It has indeed been a long and difficult season for value and the other exposures our strategy relies on. But if it changes, this fund could eventually see its day in the sun.
In other words, there hasn‚Äôt been a better opportunity to own value stocks going back over 50 years.

The spread between inexpensive and expensive stocks reached historic magnitude. He demonstrated that a number of value metrics and composites posted a value spread that was at or near the 100th percentile going back to 1967.
Perhaps a tailwind is even taking shape in front of our eyes. AQR‚Äôs Cliff Asness laid out the facts on just how attractive value investing looked recently.

We‚Äôre confident a time will come again when our strategy's headwinds turn to tailwinds. Value, trend, and small cap exposures would all potentially help performance, as likely would a long bear market in stocks (if we ever have one again...).
But we also believe the way to do well in this game is by remaining faithful to the styles that research suggests will reward investors in the long-run.

Buffett and friends stock picks, and similarly Berkshire‚Äôs stock, have gone loonnnnggg periods underperforming the broad US stock market.   While we don‚Äôt believe our strategy will continue to underperform, we do believe seasons of underperformance is often the name of the game.

But most could never have endured the roller coaster to get there. It‚Äôs easy to fantasize about the $200,000,000 finish line but think about suffering through one of Berkshire‚Äôs multiple 50% drawdowns as Buffett‚Äôs value approach fell out of style with the prevailing market regime

An investor who put $10,000 into Berkshire Hathaway in 1965 would now have about $200,000,000.

That‚Äôs Two. Hundred. Million. Dollars.

(Compared to a still respectable approximate $2mm for the broad stock market.)

In past blog posts, I‚Äôve highlighted a similar point by looking at Warren Buffett ‚Äì a staunch value investor who has remained faithful to his market approach throughout all sorts of investing styles du jour.

By the time hindsight proves that there‚Äôs been a true regime shift in the markets, Strategy B is now outperforming Strategy A, an investor who missed this shift might be down big, holding onto the old strategy or suffering an opportunity cost of not being up big in new strategy.

The challenge is that no one knows how long a season will last. Also, it can be very difficult to identify when a season is actually changing. (PS if you‚Äôre looking for a good science fiction book check out The Fifth Season.)

https://t.co/w48kIUB99j

Because we still believe in the strategy. 

Furthering that point, we believe that, with investing, no strategy dominates year-in, year-out. Instead, seasons come and go.

So, why don't we just close down this strategy like many companies do, and funnel assets into what‚Äôs working today?  (A recent study from Investment Company Institute‚Äôs ICI fact book shows that nearly half of all mutual funds from 10 years ago have shut down or merged.)

A temporary issue related to a particular market approach.

Most market neutral style funds from giant shops in the industry have been equally as stinky. We believe this reflects how this market approach simply isn‚Äôt in favor today.
Now, the only positive to this story is that anytime we get too despondent about the performance of this strategy, we remind ourselves what we believe is at the root of all this‚Ä¶

And to top it all off, the choice of hedge also hurts (S&P 500 Index)...strike 4! 

Ouch.
The broad trend hedge has hurt as the US stock market has rolled over into downtrends, only to rip right back up to new highs (strike 3).
The broad value hedge has dragged on returns as the US stock market has continued to get more expensive (strike 2).

Virtually all of them have acted as headwinds in recent years.

Value combined with momentum exposure has underperformed growth and market cap weighted indexes (strike 1).

So, how have all of these exposures impacted performance?

Poorly.

1. Gives investors exposure to stocks ranking highly on value and momentum metrics.

2. Help investors hedge their overall stock exposure incrementally, based on broad market value and trend metrics. For example, right now, it is approximately 50% hedged.

So, are we just total morons, or is the strategy broken?  Or perhaps, it's simply going through a rough patch?

Let's dig under the hood.  

At its core, the strategy seeks to accomplish two things:
(Meb: I can't mention the fund here, just the strategy, so  let's just say.....bad. You can find similar comps in the market neutral funds run by Vanguard, AQR, Gotham etc)

But prior to the beginning of the year, this strategy had been a stinker.

Just how bad?

While we originally penned this article at the end of 2020, it seems the strategy may have already taken a positive turn. Strategies with exposure to size and value factors have been outperforming the broad market since the beginning of the year, and even back to early November.

With this in mind, today, let's focus on a strategy that is assuredly "NOT crushing it," but one that we believe could be set for a rebound ‚Äì our old paper focused on buying value and momentum stocks, and hedging them based on top down broad market trend and valuation.

Were you buying stocks this past March when markets were down 30%+? Or did you wait until they‚Äôd recouped their losses?

(Meb: remember this email was sent at start of 2021)
Were you buying stocks at the depths of 2009, or did it take you some quarters/years before you were convinced it was safe?

Shouldn‚Äôt we be considering the strategies that might be nearing the beginning of their time in the sun, rather than crowding into those strategies that have been in the sun for many years now and perhaps sunburnt?

Performance chasing the hot funds and what is working right now is tempting, but is that the right decision?  

Shouldn't we rather be focusing on sound assets and strategies that are out of favor?

However, we understand performance will wax and wane. We believe every asset class and strategy will have its day in the sun, as well as a great many days in the shade, too.  

Most asset managers that have been around a few cycles have the scars to prove it.
If you've read our recent profiles of Cambria‚Äôs top performers, you would probably place us into that category too.

Truncated email here:

If you were to believe all the fund marketing emails, every single asset manager would always be "crushing it".

The reason for this hype is obvious ‚Äì it's easier to market strategies and raise assets with funds that are performing well.
